conclusion: To determine the propagation speed of light in water, use the concept of the critical angle and Snell's Law.
The critical angle is the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs, and it is \(\alpha/2\).
Snell's Law relates the angles of incidence and refraction to the refractive indices of the two media.
For the critical angle, Snell's Law becomes \(n_{\text{water}} \sin \theta_c = 1\).
The refractive index \(n\) of a medium is related to the speed of light in that medium \(v\) and the speed of light in vacuum \(c\) by \(n = \frac{c}{v}\).
The speed of light in water \(v_{\text{water}}\) can be expressed as \(v_{\text{water}} = \frac{c}{n_{\text{water}}}\).
The propagation speed of light in water is \(c \sin (\alpha/2)\).
